docs.lead_paragraph: Despite its many delights, summer also brings its fair share of pestilence. One, called babesiosis, has only recently been widely recognized as a potentially serious outdoor hazard. According to a very detailed study conducted on Block Island, R.I., it could eventually rival Lyme disease as the most common tick-borne ailment in the United States. But with reasonable precautions, neither babesiosis nor Lyme should keep you from enjoying a romp in the grass or hike in the woods.

headline.main: Personal Health: Another Reason to Guard Against Ticks

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column warns of the growing dangers posed by babesiosis, which could eventually rival Lyme disease as the most common tick-borne ailment in the United States; provides advice on how to avoid infection. Drawing (M)l

headline.main: Another Tick-Borne Disease to Guard Against
headline.print_headline: Personal Health: Another Reason to Guard Against Ticks

docs.abstract: Babesiosis, which causes flulike symptoms and can be fatal, could eventually rival Lyme disease as the most common tick-borne ailment in the United States.
docs.snippet: Babesiosis, which causes flulike symptoms and can be fatal, could eventually rival Lyme disease as the most common tick-borne ailment in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nowhere is our health care system more broken and desperate than rural Mississippi. Can an approach used in Iran help save lives?

headline.seo: What Can Mississippi’s Health Care System Learn From Iran?
headline.main: What Can Mississippi Learn From Iran?

docs.abstract: Suzy Hansen article describes the work being done by HealthConnect, an agency in Mississippi whose purpose is to address the dearth of medical services in rural areas of the state; observes that the agency's holistic, intensely personal approach and preventive approach was inspired by the primary health care system created in the 1980s in the Islamic Republic of Iran.
docs.snippet: Nowhere is our health care system more broken and desperate than rural Mississippi. Can an approach used in Iran help save lives?
